questions.stem: At a crowded café you need to look up your flight time and send a quick email. In 1–3 sentences, list the safe steps you would take before and during this short use of the café’s free Wi-Fi.

rubric.point: Turn on a trusted VPN first
Avoid typing or sending sensitive data
Rely on 2FA/antivirus already set up to catch surprises

questions.stem: While using airport Wi-Fi a full-screen pop-up claims a “critical update” is needed and urges you to click. Briefly describe how you would handle the pop-up and why.

rubric.point: Do not click or install unknown pop-ups on public Wi-Fi
Get updates only through the device’s own store or maker site later
Keep antivirus active to block hidden malware

questions.stem: After banking on hotel lobby Wi-Fi you realise you stayed logged-in. In a couple of sentences explain the immediate steps you should take to stop a possible session hijack.

rubric.point: Log out and clear browser data/cookies at once
Disconnect from the public Wi-Fi (or forget the network)
Rely on or enable 2FA to limit future misuse

questions.stem: A colleague suggests emailing payroll details over the coffee-shop Wi-Fi because “it’s just numbers.” In short, explain why this is risky and offer a safer way to share the file right now.

rubric.point: Propose waiting for trusted network, mobile data, or using a VPN
If it must be sent, encrypt or password-protect the file first

questions.stem: You must check your bank urgently but only public Wi-Fi is available. Outline, in 2–3 sentences, a layered approach that reduces the dangers described in the module.

rubric.point: Activate a reputable VPN before logging in
Use banking with 2FA/OTP so stolen login alone is useless
Log out, close browser, and disconnect from Wi-Fi right after finishing
